> @ambition119 - FYI. Github uses keywords for closing related issues. https://help.github.com/articles/closing-issues-using-keywords/ If you can use "Fixes #xyz" or "Closes #xyz" in your description, when this PR is merged, Github will automatically close the corresponding github issue.

@merlimat , will add a unit test for this change
@bputt gotcha, thank you for clarification.

@merlimat Since there are several thresholds to control the split on the bundle, so there is one scenario that only one busy topic can cause the bundle to split, I'm wondering if the split on the bundle can spread the load for that? If yes, how?

@foreversunyao, thanks for the help. Yes, it use admin api to get the stats. 
Confirmed with one usr that reported a similar issue, this could be fixed by setting advertisedAddress for both `broker.conf` and `bookkeeper.conf`.
```
# Hostname or IP address the service advertises to the outside world. If not set, the value of InetAddress.getLocalHost().getHostName() is used.
advertisedAddress=
```
@ambition119 , Thanks a lot for the help. If it is available, it would be better to add some integration tests.

In addition to the create, tenant, namespace has to be able to be used by standalone.
```shell
$ bin/pulsar standalone
$ bin/pulsar-admin tenants create my-tenant --allowed-clusters standalone
$ bin/pulsar-admin namespaces create my-tenant/my-ns
$ bin/pulsar-admin namespaces set-clusters my-tenant/my-ns --clusters standalone
```
or you can update tenant, namespace default value public/default/my-topic1, 
then run example.

@imaramos 

> Currently the producer batching is a buffer that is flushed according with batching configs. The problem is that we can loose the messages order, if some fails.

The ordering will not be lost because the client library will internally resend all the messages from the failure point. You might see duplicates (unless you enabled deduplication feature) but you'll not get ordering violation when pipelining multiple outstanding messages.

> An alternative could be adding a flush method that gives more control to the client, having the ability to flush the buffer when desired. 

We already have that method in Java and C++. We just have to expose that in Python and Go wrapper still.

Eg: 
Java: http://pulsar.apache.org/api/client/org/apache/pulsar/client/api/Producer.html#flush--
C++ : http://pulsar.apache.org/api/cpp/classpulsar_1_1_producer.html#a1cd59ffc4a23162eca39183ba4278146
rerun integration tests

@merlimat Even the duplication could be a problem, the prefered behaviour should be send everything or send nothing making it atomic and still achieving a good throughput without loosing the control over the sent messages. Dont you agree?

Is this feature more suitable for submission to the flume repository? As a sink of flume

@tuteng : 

I think there two ways to do connectors:

1) adding a connector in Flume repo, which implements Flume's plugin interfaces. 
2) adding a pulsar connector that receives data from flume or to flume, which implements Pulsar's connector interfaces.

from functionalities perspective, both 1) and 2) are doing the same thing. the differences will be - who is running the "connecting" logic. 

for 1), it is more suitable for adding the connector to flume's repository.
for 2), pulsar's main repo is probably the best location. 

either 1) or 2) can also be a separate github repo hosting at your github account, and if you want to maintain them as the versions evolve.

I think the issue here falls into the second category.

For the second catecory.
Sending data to flume is relatively easy and can be implemented using both flume-ng-client and flume-ng-sdk.
However, I have not found a better way to receive data from flume. Flume officials have implemented various sink to send out data.For example https://github.com/apache/flume/tree/trunk/flume-ng-sinks
If flume agent is added, it seems that it is also possible.

I don't know if I understand it correctly.
@sijie
how about batch message ack in consumer?

@david-streamlio we can add some the methods from Function Context to Sink/Source Context.  However, there is a major difference between Function Context and Sink/Source Context.  Function Context is meant context for the message currently being processed while Sink/Source Context provide general context for the Sink and Source in general.
That's fine, just add a subset that makes sense, which would include the getLogger() method

looks like https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-broker-common/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/broker/ServiceConfiguration.java#L104 , **brokerServicePort** has no "required" attributes, so it will prompt an **java.lang.NullPointerException** exception, and don't do any check further .

@foreversunyao In fact, the parameters have been checked but the error log is not printed as expected (see https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-broker/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/PulsarBrokerStarter.java#L277). I replaced this line by following:
`System.out.println(">>>" + String.format("Uncaught exception in thread %s: %s", thread.getName(), exception.getMessage()));`
it printed the log as expected in pulsar-broker-$broker.out as below:
`>>>Uncaught exception in thread main: Required zookeeperServers is null,Required clusterName is null`
@sijie How do you think about this, should we print the exception in stack trace?
@foreversunyao yeah, it continues the for loop and appends all required fields error then throws it .

> @sautran , is it a reproduced issue ? or is it related the issue which was fixed recently #3373

sorry, I wrong related to #3373, this issue unresolved.

master code run also occur this exception, modify code like commit then example run normal:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20353043/51537911-d2a72400-1e8a-11e9-80a0-5f7030e54e6b.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20353043/51537927-dc308c00-1e8a-11e9-94fe-e43df0b85c9d.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20353043/51537947-e9e61180-1e8a-11e9-9aa7-20258cc29969.png)

@foreversunyao I think a better approach would be to just retry the operation (read-modify-write) when receiving a `BadVersion`  error from ZooKeeper. This won't require to create (and delete) an additional z-node. 

More-over, the policies are stored in global-zookeeper and we don't want to have ephemeral z-nodes in there, rather just regular key-value pairs.

run integration tests

@bputt This would be kind of addressed in 2.3. The changes were described in https://github.com/apache/pulsar/wiki/PIP-24%3A-Simplify-memory-settings . 

The implementation was actually done in BookKeeper and will be available in 4.9.0 release (which is currently being voted). Once that's available, we'll add the hooks in Pulsar broker as well to ensure that under any circumstances, the broker will restart when a OOM exception occurs. (at the same mitigations for that not to happen as easily are also there).
@merlimat do you have an expected release date for 2.3?

This is a test file

1. set conf/nifi.properties, like  [configure-site-to-site](http://nifi.apache.org/docs/nifi-docs/html/user-guide.html#configure-site-to-site-server-nifi-instance)

```file
nifi.remote.input.socket.port=10443
```
2. start nifi

```shell
bin/nifi.sh start
```
3. open a web browser and navigate to http://localhost:8080/nifi 

4. sample NiFi receive data from Pulsar:

```file
1 chose Input Port and set Port Name, The Port Name corresponding to pulsar NiFiSink portName.
2 add Processor PutFile and config.
3 start NiFi Flow
```

5.sample NiFi receive data from Pulsar:

```file
1 add Processor GutFile and config.
2 chose Output Port and set Port Name, The Port Name corresponding to pulsar NiFiSource portName.
3 start NiFi Flow
```

the following kafka producer can work however send very slowly, but the pulsar-client (`bin/pulsar-client consume persistent://public/default/test -n 100 -s "consumer-test" -t "Failover"`) cannot consume any msgs:
```
public class TestPulsar {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    String topic = "persistent://public/default/test";

    Properties props = new Properties();
    props.put("bootstrap.servers", "pulsar://lhccmh3:6650");

    props.put("key.serializer", IntegerSerializer.class.getName());
    props.put("value.serializer", StringSerializer.class.getName());

    Producer<Integer, String> producer = new KafkaProducer<>(props);

    for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
      producer.send(new ProducerRecord<Integer, String>(topic, i, Integer.toString(i)));
      System.out.println(String.format(">>>Message %s sent successfully", i));
    }

    producer.close();
  }
}
```

@rdhabalia ~~Can you describe the sequence of events and what would be the "bad" state?~~

Re-read the description...

Hi all! just my 2 cents, isn't `volatile` also be needed in [this field](https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-broker/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/broker/service/persistent/PersistentDispatcherSingleActiveConsumer.java#L57) since updates and reads could be performed by different threads?

run java8 tests
run integration tests

@lovelle yes, but it will not be fixed by just making it volatile and it has to be atomic because it is being updated by multiple threads and it can also create possible NPE. So, i have created separate PR: #3413 to address theses issues.
@rdhabalia you are absolutely right! I was thinking of using `AtomicReference` for cas operations, but the proposed solution on #3413 is even better! nice catch-up !!

Excellent solution! just a question/proposal, has anyone ever considered of using annotations to document better thread safety like `@ThreadSafe` at a class level? A lot of people use [jcip-annotations](https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/net.jcip/jcip-annotations) for this purpose and gives a clearer visibility about thread safety.
